search_result.title: 'The Gray Man': Meet Mark Greaney, Memphis author behind books ...
search_result.text:
About a thousand copies of Mark Greaney books sell each day, according to the Memphis author.

That's a staggering number — and it's likely to jump dramatically this month, for a couple of reasons.

First, Tuesday is the release date for Greaney's 20th novel, "Armored."

According to a synopsis on the author's website, the book is an "explosive new action-adventure" in which "a rag-tag team of American security contractors fight for their lives in Mexico's mountainous cartel country."

Second, the first Greaney-inspired movie arrives soon — and it's a big one.

Destined to propel Greaney awareness into what the author calls "uncharted territory," "The Gray Man" hits theaters July 15 and makes its Netflix debut July 22. The movie is adapted from the first of 11 novels that showcase the action-espionage talents of Greaney's signature hero, the so-called "Gray Man," a CIA agent turned assassin-for-hire.

'The Gray Man' movie

"The Gray Man" is being launched as the opening shot in what Netflix hopes will become a salvo: an action-adventure franchise to rival Jason Bourne and the Tom Cruise "Mission: Impossible" films.

With a production budget of $200 million, "The Gray Man" is the most expensive movie yet from Netflix. But what has raised expectations is not the film's budget but its pedigree: It was produced and directed by Marvel-associated brothers Joe and Anthony Russo, who previously helmed some of the biggest blockbusters of all time, including "Avengers: Endgame" (No. 2 on the all-time U.S. box-office chart), "Avengers: Infinity War" (No. 6) and two "Captain America" movies.

The cast is similarly high-powered. Ryan Gosling stars as Court Gentry, the "Gray Man," while the former Captain America, Chris Evans, is Gentry's psychopathic nemesis, Lloyd Hansen. Supporting players include Alfre Woodard and Billy Bob Thornton.

Greaney already has topped the New York Times best-seller list, but "we really expect this will kick him up a serious notch," said Tom Colgan, Greaney's New York-based career-long editor at Berkley.

"No matter what we do in making people aware of the Gray Man, we can’t beat what a movie or TV show does," Colgan said. "There are going to be people who have never heard of the Gray Man before they see the movie, but when they realize it's based on a book, we think many of them will want to read that book. And once they do, they'll be hooked — and then they've got 10 years of books to go through."

To meet the expected demand, two different paperback movie tie-in editions of "The Gray Man" become available July 12. Reading the blurbs printed on the opening pages suggest readers should beware of more than paper cuts.

"Jack Reacher" creator Lee Child describes the 2009 novel as "hard, fast and unflinching," while techno-thriller writer James Rollins compares it to "a well-honed dagger: sharp, merciless, and deadly." Rollins adds that the book "strikes with the impact of a bullet to the chest." Ouch.

'He knows what he's writing about'

In any event, Greaney, 54, knows his way around bullets and the instruments that discharge them.

Unlike some armchair adventurers whose names decorate book spines, Greaney — pronounced "Grainy," not "Greeny" — is an inveterate world traveler.

"I like to get my own impression of a place and the people and the politics and how their police work," said Greaney, who has traveled for his books to such locales as China, Russia and what he calls "probably the most dangerous space in the Western hemisphere," the drug cartel-influenced territory near the Mexican state of Sinaloa.

As a tall (6-foot-3), physically fit, cleancut and not exactly young lone male poking around off-the-beaten path locations, Greaney sometimes attracts attention, he said, including suspicious looks, tails and bugs. "When I was in China working on a book, they know the books I write, they know it's going to be about Chinese intelligence or war with China, so, yes, they listen," he said, referring to listening devices he said were found in his hotel room and a car for tourists. "Of course, maybe they listen to everybody."

He also has had extensive training in firearms, close combat, stunt driving and battlefield medicine. If you need a tourniquet to stop the bleeding or pneumothoracic treatment because you've been shot through the lung, Greaney can help, he says.

"The thing that sets Mark apart is his work ethic," said Colgan, 60, an editor for 30 years at Berkley/Penguin/Random House, where he specializes in mysteries and thrillers (his client list includes another Memphis author, Joshua Hood). "He never takes the easy way out. It certainly pays off in his writing. He knows what he's writing about."

Like such other popular fiction writers as Stephen King and Nora Roberts, Greaney is no slouch: He has published 20 novels in 13 years.

Eleven of these are "Gray Man" books, which carry such genre-identifying titles as "Gunmetal Gray," "Mission Critical" and "Ballistic."

He also wrote seven books in association with techno-thriller superstar Tom Clancy and the Clancy estate; three of these were billed as collaborations with Clancy, while the other four continued various Clancy series after that author's 2013 death. Greaney was introduced to Clancy by Colgan, who also was Clancy's editor; the connection greatly expanded Greaney's audience. "It gets your name out there," Greaney said.

Greaney also has penned two stand-alone novels, "Armored," and 2019's "Red Metal," a collaboration with H. Ripley Rawlings IV, a lieutenant colonel in the Marines. Like most Greaney books, "Red Metal" is speculative but grounded in persuasive political theory and factual geography and history; in this case, the plot anticipates the current Ukraine chaos by imagining a Russian invasion beyond its Western border.

The books generally range from 150,000 to 217,000 words in length. "Armored," which retails for $28, is close to 500 pages. "My problem isn't making them too short," Greaney said.

Colgan praised Greaney's technique, which a New York Times reviewer described as "so propulsive, so explosive, that flipping the pages feels like playing the ultimate video game."

"There's a sense of propulsion, but Mark knows exactly where those beats are," Colgan said. "He knows when to stop and let the reader catch his breath and then move quickly again.”

A White Station High, Memphis State alum

A lifelong Memphian whose local-legend father, the late Ed Greaney, spent more than half a century in news and public affairs at WMC-TV Channel 5, Greaney grew up on Cole Road, "so I've made it about a mile, as the crow flies," he said. He now occupies a large home on a street in the heart of East Memphis that in the past decade has seen many of its 1960s ranch houses replaced with greatly expanded residences. He shares the home with his wife, Allison Anthony Greaney, a painter; his three teenaged stepchildren, Ava, Sophie and Kemmons; and four rescue dogs, named Lobo, Ziggy, Winnie and Mars.

He used to write at Starbucks, but he's too recognizable to do that now, he said: He can't get much work done because of the interruptions from readers and would-be authors seeking career advice. Instead, he writes in a large back house that is located past the swimming pool and decorated by his wife in what Greaney calls "masculine" fashion, with carved tusks, sculpted greyhounds, and an antler chandelier. One wall is dedicated to mementos and photographs of his father.

The wide couches and comfortable chairs allow Greaney to stretch his left leg, when necessary: Surgery after a soccer injury when he was in his early 30s left him with partial paralysis of that limb, a condition that scuttled his adulthood dream of joining the military. "I turn myself into RoboCop below the left knee," he said, brandishing an orthopedic brace.

BOOKS FOR YOUNG READERS: Meet Kathlyn J. Kirkwood, a South Memphis native who helped make MLK Day a federal holiday

A 1985 graduate of White Station High School, Greaney majored in political science and international relations at what was then known as Memphis State University. "Decades later, it proved useful," he commented, referring to the plots of his novels.

After college, he spent years in the international import/export business, all the while continuing his lifelong habit of reading nonfiction books about the military and law enforcement. He began to pursue fiction writing seriously in the 2000s, and wrote three novels that remain unpublished. But they showed promise, and Greaney was able to acquire an agent, who brought Greaney's fourth completed book, "The Gray Man," to the attention of Berkley. The first edition was a mass-market paperback.

The book sold well, leading to Greaney's longtime association with Berkley and earning him the opportunity to be the first author to extend the Clancy franchise. What's more, movie rights to "The Gray Man" sold before it even was published, "so I've spent the entire length of my career waiting for this movie."

Meanwhile, "Armored" has been optioned by Sony Pictures and "Transformers" director Michael Bay. "It's basically half 'Apocalypse Now' and half 'Black Hawk Down,'" Greaney says of the book. "There's a lot of action but also a mysterious atmosphere."

All the while, Greaney has worked to stay current on technology and military strategy. He annually visits Tactical Response, a Camden, Tennessee-based company that provides "the highest end firearms and tactical training possible to the legally armed," according to its website. As a successful author, "I'm a novelty there now, but I started going even before my first book came out," he said.

'Extraordinarily satisfied' with Netflix movie

Greaney said he wasn't actively involved in the production of "The Gray Man," although he met with the Russos to discuss the project before the start of shooting (an appropriate term, in this case, considering the movie's rat-a-tat firepower).

He said he's "extraordinarily satisfied" with the movie, based on what he's seen so far. "The promises made to me by the Russo brothers, they absolutely lived up to everything they said they were going to do, which I didn't expect. They capture the heart and the soul of the story."

"Heart" is a key to the character, according to Colgan.

"Unlike James Bond, stuff does not always go the way he planned," Colgan said. "In a Gray Man story, he has all these obstacles to overcome, and he just keeps pushing."

"I just wanted to think about the psychology of someone who would be in this situation," said Greaney, pointing out that his assassin hero sleeps in a closet instead of a bed because of his "paranoia issues."

"Every novel stands on its own, but there is a character arc," Greaney said. "He's gotten a little more cynical but he's also gotten a little more adept at navigating relationships."

Greaney and his wife are schedule to attend "The Gray Man" world premiere in Los Angeles on July 13. If the movie is a success, that trip could mark the start of many visits to Hollywood for the author. Even so, Greaney said he plans to remain in Memphis. "I love to travel, I love to leave," he said. "But I love to come back."

Mark Greaney

"Armored": Greaney will give a talk and sign copies of his new novel at 2 p.m. Saturday, July 9, at Novel at 387 Perkins Ext. To reserve a copy, visit novelmemphis.com.

"The Gray Man": The movie based on Greaney's novel opens July 15 in theaters in Memphis and around the nation. It debuts July 22 on Netflix.

For more information on the author and his work, visit markgreaneybooks.com.

New York CNN Business —

After the pandemic pummeled its business, the movie industry is counting on a comeback. The good news for theaters is they couldn’t ask for a better film to kick off the summer.

Marvel’s “Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness” hits theaters this weekend. It’s one of the most anticipated films of the year from Hollywood’s most reliable brand.

The film, which stars Benedict Cumberbatch, debuts in more than 4,000 theaters and is expected to make $170 million to $185 million in North America. Some industry analysts believe the film could break the $200 million opening barrier, which would make it the ninth film ever to do so.

The film made $90 million on Friday, its opening day, which included Thursday previews. That’s the 7th biggest opening day ever, and already tops the entire opening weekend of the original “Doctor Strange” film in 2016. The film has already made $229 million globally, per Disney (DIS).

Such a strong start could create some momentum at a time when theaters are finding themselves in a stronger position than they’ve been since the start of the pandemic.

“It’s hard to overstate the importance of this summer”

The summer of 2020 was a catastrophe for Hollywood.

Films were scarce (and nonexistent), as theaters struggled to turn on their marquees and the US box office brought in only $176 million, according to Comscore (SCOR).

That’s $176 million total for the entire summer, or $4.1 billion less than the summer of 2019, less than what “Doctor Strange” alone could make this weekend. The movie business rebounded last summer, bringing in $1.7 million domestically, but it still lagged behind pre-pandemic numbers.

The box office so far this year is catching up, and it’s showing signs of recovery with hits like February’s “Uncharted,” March’s “The Batman” and April’s “Sonic The Hedgehog 2” leading the way.

The summer slate of films could boost the good box office vibes even more.

“It’s hard to overstate the importance of this summer for the movie industry,” Shawn Robbins, chief analyst at Boxoffice.com, told CNN Business. “We’ve seen clear demand for a return to big movies in theaters, but this summer presents the best test so far.”

Robbins believes that the top earners of this summer may “approach or perhaps exceed pre-pandemic standards.”

Beyond blockbuster Marvel films, which include “Doctor Strange” and July’s “Thor: Love and Thunder,” the summer is full of all types of films that could find success.

They start with “Top Gun: Maverick,” the sequel to the beloved 1986 action film starring Tom Cruise. “Jurassic World: Dominion,” is the latest entry in the dinosaur saga, and “Elvis,” a biopic about The King starring Tom Hanks as Col. Tom Parker. Notable family films include “Lightyear” from Pixar and “Minions: The Rise of Gru.” Then there’s “Nope,” Jordan Peele’s latest horror film.

It’s not just about money

“We’re moving further away from a point when the pandemic alone can be blamed for under-performances,” Robbins said. “This summer may demonstrate how much balance there can be as the industry adapts and improves.”

That’s important not just for this summer’s box office, but for the rest of the year.

“Summer has always been vitally important for theaters, and the success of these all-important 18 weeks sets the tone for the entire year’s performance,” Paul Dergarabedian, senior media analyst at Comscore, told CNN Business.

He noted that summer is “traditionally responsible for 40% on average of the annual box-office.”

This year the summer isn’t just about money, it’s about symbolism.

The pandemic is still ongoing and theaters have a long way to go before they truly bounce back. But analysts believe there’s reason for optimism.

“The success the industry has seen so far this year is great news for theaters that have spent the past two years methodically and patiently creating building blocks of normalcy,” Dergarabedian said. “All of it was to get to something approaching a normal summer movie marketplace at the multiplex, and we may be finally getting there.”

The Associated Press

Beyoncé ruled the box office this weekend.

Her concert picture, “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé,” opened in first place with $21 million in North American ticket sales, according to estimates from AMC Theatres Sunday.

The post-Thanksgiving, early December box office is notoriously slow, but “Renaissance” defied the odds. Not accounting for inflation, it’s the first time a film has opened over $20 million on this weekend in 20 years (since “The Last Samurai”).

Beyoncé wrote, directed and produced “Renaissance,” which is focused on the tour for her Grammy-winning album. It debuted in 2,539 theaters in the U.S. and Canada, as well as 94 international territories, where it earned $6.4 million from 2,621 theaters.

“On behalf of AMC Theatres Distribution and the entire theatrical industry, we thank Beyoncé for bringing this incredible film directly to her fans,” said Elizabeth Frank, AMC Theatres executive vice president of worldwide programming, in a statement. “To see it resonate with fans and with film critics on a weekend that many in the industry typically neglect is a testament to her immense talent, not just as a performer, but as a producer and director.”

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Though “Renaissance” did not come close to matching the $92.8 million debut of “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” in October, it’s still a very good start for a concert film. No one expected “Renaissance” to match “The Eras Tour,” which is wrapping up its theatrical run soon with over $250 million globally. Prior to Swift, the biggest concert film debuts (titles held by Miley Cyrus and Justin Bieber for their 2008 and 2011 films) had not surpassed the unadjusted sum of $32 million.

The 39-city, 56-show “Renaissance” tour, which kicked off in Stockholm, Sweden in May and ended in Kansas City, Missouri in the fall, made over $500 million and attracted over 2.7 million concertgoers. Swift’s ongoing “Eras Tour,” with 151 dates, is expected to gross some $1.4 billion.

Both Beyoncé and Swift chose to partner with AMC Theatres to distribute their films, as opposed to a traditional studio. Both superstars have been supportive of one another, making splashy appearances at the other’s premieres. Both had previously released films on Netflix (“Miss Americana” and “Homecoming”). And both are reported to be receiving at least 50% of ticket sales.

Movie tickets to the show were more expensive than average, around $23.32 versus Swift’s $20.78, according to data firm EntTelligence.

Critics and audiences gave “Renaissance” glowing reviews – it’s sitting at 100% on Rotten Tomatoes and got a coveted A+ CinemaScore from opening weekend audiences who were polled. EntTelligence also estimates that the audience, around 900,000 strong, skewed a little older than Swift’s.

Lionsgate’s “The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes” fell to second place in its third weekend with an estimated $14.5 million. The prequel has now earned over $121 million domestically.

“Godzilla Minus One" took third place on the North American charts with $11 million from 2,308 locations — the biggest opening for a foreign film in the U.S. this year. The well-reviewed Japanese blockbuster distributed by Toho International cost only $15 million to produce and has already earned $23 million in Japan. Toho’s 33rd Godzilla film is set in the aftermath of World War II, stars Ryunosuke Kamiki and was directed by Takashi Yamazaki.

“This year, we made a concentrated effort to answer the demand of the marketplace and make Godzilla globally accessible across many different platforms,” said Koji Ueda, President of Toho Global, in a statement.

“Trolls Band Together” landed in fourth place in its third weekend with $7.6 million, bringing its domestic total to $74.8 million.

Fifth place went to Disney’s “Wish,” which fell 62% from its underwhelming first weekend, with $7.4 million from 3,900 locations. Globally, it’s now made $81.6 million. The studio’s other major film in theaters, “The Marvels” is also winding down in its fourth weekend with a disastrous global tally of $197 million against the reported $300 million it cost to make and market the superhero film.

In its second weekend, Ridley Scott’s “Napoleon” earned an estimated $7.1 million from 3,500 locations. Produced by Apple Original Films and distributed by Sony Pictures, the film starring Joaquin Phoenix has now made $45.7 million domestically against a $200 million budget.

search_result.title: Which Pixar film has rocketed to the top of the box office? | CNN ...
search_result.text:
New York CNN Business —

Pixar is one of the most popular brands in animation as well as one of the most important studios in Disney’s media kingdom. But it has been a while since audiences could go to a theater to see one of its films.

After releasing its last three features directly on Disney+, the studio returns to the cineplex this weekend with “Lightyear” — a film based on the popular toy space ranger, Buzz Lightyear.

Since 1995’s “Toy Story,” Pixar’s first major film, the studio’s movies have made $14.7 billion at the global box office. But which of its movies made the most?

Here’s a list of the franchise’s biggest blockbusters at the US box office, adjusted for inflation, according to Comscore (SCOR).

5. Toy Story 2

"Toy Story 2" found box office success by bringing back everyone's favorite animated toys Disney/Pixar/Moviestore/Shutterstock

Year: 1999

Box office haul: $245.8 million

Adjusted for inflation: $445 million

It would’ve been difficult for “Toy Story 2” not to be a blockbuster, given that the film is the sequel to “Toy Story” — one of the most beloved animated movies of all time.

The second installment not only brought back popular characters Woody (voiced by Tom Hanks) and Buzz Lightyear (voiced by Tim Allen), it also added new characters to Andy’s toy chest, including Jessie the Yodeling Cowgirl (voiced by Joan Cusack.)

“Toy Story 2” didn’t mess with the winning formula of the original and it paid off. The film was a hit with audiences and critics, garnering a perfect score on review site Rotten Tomatoes.

4. Toy Story 3

"Toy Story 3" was the first Pixar film to make $1 billion at the global box office. Disney/Pixar/Moviestore/Shutterstock

Year: 2010

Box office haul: $415 million

Adjusted for inflation: $481.8 million

In 2010, Pixar producers had to ask themselves, would audiences still care about the adventures of Woody and Buzz more than a decade after “Toy Story 2”? The answer was a resounding, “yes.”

“Toy Story 3” — which has the toys dealing with a grown up Andy who is on his way to college — was the first Pixar film to take in $1 billion worldwide and is regarded by many fans as one of the studio’s best.

The film was also nominated for Best Picture and won two Academy Awards for Best Original Song and Best Animated Film.

3. Finding Dory

"Finding Dory" recaptured the box office magic of "Finding Nemo" more than a decade later. Disney/Pixar/Moviestore/Shutterstock

Year: 2016

Box office haul: $486.2 million

Adjusted for inflation: $514.9 million

Sequels have been good to Pixar at the box office. Case in point: “Finding Dory.”

The sequel to “Finding Nemo” — released 13 years after the original — brought audiences back to Pixar’s underwater world. This time the focus shifted to finding Dory — the forgetful Blue Tang voiced by Ellen DeGeneres.

The film reeled in the biggest ever opening for an animated movie at the time, and was Pixar’s second film to gross $1 billion worldwide.

2. Finding Nemo

"Finding Nemo" is the only non-sequel in Pixar's top five highest-grossing films. Disney/Pixar/Moviestore/Shutterstock

Year: 2003

Box office haul: $339.7 million

Adjusted for inflation: $516 million

“Finding Nemo” is the only non-sequel among Pixar’s top five highest-grossing films, and with good reason.

The film — which told the tale of clown fish Marlin trying to find his son Nemo — was a sensation with both kids and adults. Critics loved it too. Roger Ebert gave the movie four stars and said, “the use of color, form and movement make the film a delight even apart from its story.”

“Finding Nemo” just kept swimming at the box office, turning into a classic and one of Pixar’s biggest hits.

1. The Incredibles 2

"The Incredibles 2" holds the largest opening for an animated film ever. Pixar Animation Studios/Walt Disney Pictures/Zuma Press

Year: 2018

Box office haul: $608.5 million

Adjusted for inflation: $611.9 million

Remember when I said sequels have been good to Pixar?

“The Incredibles 2” — the next chapter in the story of a superhero family trying balance raising kids with saving the world — is Pixar’s highest-grossing title at the global box office, bringing in more than $1.2 billion worldwide.

The Brad Bird film also notched the biggest ever opening for an animated film, debuting to $182 million in 2018.

Of course that’s no surprise, since if Disney is good at anything, it’s animation and superheroes.

search_result.title: Bathed in light: Destiny 2 review | Technobubble
search_result.text:
Jason Hidalgo

jhidalgo@rgj.com

Technobubble covers games, gadgets, technology and all things geek. Follow Technobubble poobah Jason Hidalgo’s shenanigans on Twitter @jasonhidalgo or his Tabiasobi Youtube channel.

Crashing a bathing ceremony is honestly something I never thought I’d see in a first-person shooter.

And yet that’s exactly what you and your team of crack-shot guardians are required to do should you decide to partake in Destiny 2’s first major raid.

Then again, it’s a much better surprise than the one I experienced while playing the original Destiny right after launch. Thanks to its ambitious-looking previews, I expected the first Destiny to weave this great big narrative tapestry while providing exciting public events that would have players from all over organically come together to take out a spawning big bad as you explore the game’s world.

As someone who likes MMOs and cooperative PVE shooting, Destiny 2 was one of my most anticipated games of 2014. Then the game came out with surprisingly sparse content, a story you find out about mostly off-game, and public matchmaking that was MIA. It almost felt like the gaming equivalent of clickbait.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

The game would eventually get its second wind with the release of “The Taken King,” thanks to some notable improvements. By that time, however, Destiny continued to be hobbled by the shortcomings of that initial launch, at least in the minds of players who left the game.

This makes the launch of Destiny’s follow-up a crucial time for the fate of the franchise. The first Destiny sold well due to the goodwill that Bungie built up with the Halo franchise. The sour taste from the original game, however, means Destiny 2 doesn’t have as much wiggle room. It had to start out with a bang.

And start out with a bang it did, literally, as the campaign thrusts you into the middle of an all-out assault on The Last City. Spearheading the charge against humanity’s final remaining bastion is the Red Legion, led by the Cabal Empire’s brutal and charismatic leader Dominus Ghaul. The battle ends up as a power struggle for the Traveler, more specifically, the Traveler's Light. For Guardians, the Light is a source of power literally and figuratively — a blessing that bestows strength and recognition of humanity as the Chosen race. For the Red Legion, it’s something to be controlled, a gift that’s currently wasted on an unworthy race.

The initial result of the battle pushes the narrative of Destiny 2 as the power play between the Guardians and the Red Legion unfolds. It also tackles the theme of the haves and the have-nots in multiple ways, not just in the form of who controls the Light between the Guardians and the Red Legion but between humans imbued with the Light and humans who never received its power in the first place. I won’t delve into the story beyond this to avoid spoiling it to folks who want to experience it on their own.

Needless to say, it feels that Destiny 2 has more storytelling in its first hour than the entire original game did when it launched. This is a plus for someone like myself who still likes to play shooters for their campaign. The improved storytelling and more purposeful narrative made me want to keep pushing through the campaign to see what happens even after I‘ve unlocked the privilege to do co-op and dabble in the game’s online features.

Another plus is the ability to bring over your character from the first game, provided you reached Level 20 and finished the Black Garden. Destiny 2 was able to detect my save file from the previous game on my PS4, though you pretty much only get to keep your look and not much else. After the initial battle, you will eventually unlock one of the new subclasses in the game depending on the class you are using. Since my previous character was the mage-style Warlock, I ended up rocking the Dawnblade subclass at first, which replaces the Sunsinger and can launch solar blades from a distance and create either a healing or empowering circle. You can also unlock previous subclasses such as the Voidwalker and Stormcaller, with a few tweaks. The warrior-like Titan and rogue-ish Hunter classes also get one new subclass each, as well as a couple of returning subclasses.

Other familiar touches from the previous game include patrols, public events, Crucible PVP and, of course, Raids. Heroic Public Events, for example, are unlocked in real time during such events by fulfilling prerequisites such as destroying other key targets before taking down a public event’s main objective. This makes the game harder but also gives you better loot — a big raison d’etre for any Destiny player — and more Glimmer currency points if you complete the mission. Just like the first game, Destiny 2 also doesn’t truly start until you finish the story. Raids continue to be the epitome of challenge and cooperation, boasting multi-phase mechanics that require players to not only know what to do but also coordinate with the proper timing lest they fail an objective or end up with a team wipe. In the case of the first raid event, Leviathan, you will need to do things like step on and hold objective points and shoot the right portal openings, all the while trying to survive against tough foes.

One improvement over the original is the inclusion of Guided Games. It isn’t quite full-fledged public matchmaking but it’s a helpful feature for solo players looking to get into a group (or vice-versa) for tackling endgame content without having to join clans or gather up friends. Do be warned that playing with random groups can make it tougher to finish strikes or raids — especially the latter — due to the coordination that they require. Nevertheless, Guided Games are a nice option to have.

In addition to patching up some of the holes from the previous game, Destiny 2 also builds on the things that the first game excelled at. At the top of the list is the gunplay, which continues to be rock solid. As much as certain aspects of the original Destiny fell short, one thing that was great was the actual shooting gameplay, which felt nice and tight. Another is the game’s sound, which remains impressive in Destiny 2. While talking with a friend who loves the game, I asked if anything about Destiny 2 stood out to him in particular and he responded by saying, “wear headphones,” and there’s good reason for that. From its excellent musical score to the top-notch sound effects, audio is one department where Destiny 2 does not disappoint. The visuals, meanwhile, continue to impress and I quite liked seeing more traditional Earth environs in addition to the game’s familiar galactic locales.

That being said, the game also suffers from its share issues, some of new and some carried over from the previous game. Microtransactions, for example, feel just a bit more pervasive this time around. You can use real money to buy Silver, which you can then use to trade for Bright Engrams with NPC Tess Everis, for example. These Engrams can then be used for a chance to unlock special loot. This includes your typical cosmetics but they also can unlock things that can impact gameplay, including weapon and armor mods that improve your stats.

To be fair, you can eventually earn Bright Engrams in-game each time you level up after hitting Level 20. Anything that affects gameplay, however, is often seen as a dividing line between “harmless” microtransactions and those that influence players to use real money to acquire a gameplay advantage. It’s not as blatant as Evolve but folks who don’t like microtransactions likely won’t appreciate the move.

Another related change that’s seen as unfriendly to players involves shaders. Instead of unlocking them permanently, they are now treated as one-time use items that also have to be applied individually to each piece of armor or gear, meaning you need more of them to have a matching colored set. Granted, you can acquire a bunch of them through the course of playing the game. Nevertheless, it can still be seen by critics as a cynical ploy to nudge people toward paying for microtransactions to acquire shaders via special loot as well. This also ties into the loot earned in raids, which some feel don’t reward players enough items for the time investment required to do them successfully, especially when RNG is being miserly toward you. The result is that you’ll either need to spend real money for a chance at getting stuff earlier or grind even more, with the latter being something that can get out of hand in Destiny 2 as the time investment required can skyrocket quickly. Speaking of time, some campaign missions require you to be at a certain level, requiring you to, well, grind in order to progress the narrative. On the plus side, the overall grind doesn't feel as draining as the previous game, particularly for end game.

Overall, Destiny 2 is a step in the right direction for Bungie’s current shooting franchise. As such, I look forward to see how the game grows and continues to iterate on its solid foundation.

FINAL THOUGHTS

Destiny 2 is a welcome follow-up that rights several of the wrongs that tripped up the original game when it launched. The grind can admittedly be draining at times and its treatment of microtransactions will disappoint some players. It’s excellent gunplay, however, combined with a more fleshed out narrative and a nice selection of online activities to tackle either solo or with teammates brings the series closer to realizing its own destiny — pun so totally intended.

search_result.title: Pedal to metal: Call of Duty Black Ops 3 review | Technobubble
search_result.text:
Jason Hidalgo

jhidalgo@rgj.com

Technobubble covers games, gadgets, technology and all things geek. Follow Technobubble poobah Jason Hidalgo's shenanigans on Twitter @jasonhidalgo

What do you do when it feels like everything has already been done before?

That's the conundrum that faces the popular Call of Duty franchise every time it drops a new entry to an audience that's seen it all when it comes to the first-person shooter genre.

For the most part, every iteration of the modern Call of Duty franchise relies on baby steps. There may be a few changes with perks here or the presentation there but the base shooting experience itself feels largely unchained.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

With the genre now past the saturation point combined with the appearance of new challengers such as Titanfall that have tried to shake up the old shooter formula, the need to iterate with extra purpose is even more crucial for Call of Duty. In that sense, I can understand the decision to double down on last year's release by going the ultra modern warfare route with "Call of Duty: Black Ops III." After all, to really change gameplay, you'll need new mechanics that perhaps can't be done through your regular soldier. The question now is whether that decision pays off without diluting what I consider one of the Black Ops series's biggest strengths: its campaign.

For its latest tale, Black Ops III skips past the more traditional Cold War vibe of its predecessors and goes all futuristic with a dash of the metaphysical. This time, you play the role of a cybernetically enhanced soldier — which comes with a selection of cool tech and enhancements while also raising questions about one's own humanity. The mechanical augments make their presence on the battlefield via a smart HUD that tracks foes and hot spots, for example, and also have the ability to hack machines and other tech on the field. To customize your experience, you can use cyber cores and rigs to further improve your capabilities.

The campaign gets a touch of law and order as well with the half-human, half amazing appearance of Christopher Meloni and his cybernetic parts. I pretty much started hearing a gavel sound effect in my head every time he popped up because, well, I'm a strange man, that's why. Although the campaign is competent and employs the top notch production values that have become Call of Duty's calling card, I must admit that it's the weakest of the Black Ops games to date. As someone who's a big fan of campaign modes in shooters, I just didn't feel the requisite emotional connection with Black Ops III's characters, with all the virtual stuff leading to an almost detached experience for me. Ultimately, it felt just like a typical shooter campaign, especially when compared to the excellent storytelling of the first Black Ops game. I do appreciate the co-op mode for the campaign, though, which allows up to four players to tackle missions together.

In contrast to the campaign, Black Ops III's multiplayer modes are the main strength of the game. Thanks to the addition of various features to the series' solid shooting mechanics, multiplayer provides a fresher experience instead of feeling like a complete rehash of past games. At the top of the list is the addition of specialists. Each come with their own unique skill sets and abilities from the bruiser-style Ruin to the assassination specialist Spectre. Each of the nine also can be ranked up individually in addition to universal and weapons experience progression, providing variations on the stock shooting experience.

Beantown blues: Fallout 4 review | Technobubble

Blizzcon 2015 recap: From Warcraft movie to Blizzard game updates | Technobubble

Tales From the Borderlands Episode 5: Vault of the Traveler review | Technobubble

It's a nice change from the archetypal grunt you typically get from past games. Mobility, for example, is enhanced with the addition of a "chain movement" system that includes thrusts jumps, slides and Titanfall style wall running. This adds both speed and verticality to the traditional shooter gameplay, which work well with the game's new multi-level maps. It's fun to dive underwater near your spawn point, for example, swim behind enemy lines, pop off three enemy soldiers from behind their back, then thrust and wall run your way to safety. The game also comes with a new gunsmith system for extra weapon customization as well as a paint shop that allows for custom graphics.

Zombies mode also gets a reworked noir-style story involving four social misfits in Morg City who have, uh, certain debts to society. Production values are improved over the past with the addition of some recognizable personalities in the mix. I remember playing with my little cousin and saying, "Is it me or does that dude look like Ron Perlman?" My cousin asked who Ron Perlman was and I said he's the guy with the fancy shoes who — spoiler alert — got eaten in Pacific Rim. Naturally, he answers "Oh, you mean Hellboy." Yup, that's what I meant, too. Then I go, "By the way, does that magician guy look like Jeff Goldblum or what?" Then my cousin goes, "Who's Jeff Goldblum?" I think I'm starting to feel old.

Zombies mode adds an extra element of Will Ferrell-level strategery and the ability to transform into a powerful creature for some added oomph against the undead. You can also manually unlock new areas the farther you get in rounds, though this also requires paying attention to coordination as it's easy to get wiped out once your team gets separated. All in all, zombies mode provides a deeper experience that breathes new life to Black Ops' trademark skirmishes with the undead, especially with its new experience progression. As far as my main complaints with Zombies mode, these include long loading times and — at least during the first week of the game's release — annoying connection hiccups.

FINAL THOUGHTS

Call of Duty: Black Ops III flips the script a bit by serving what's arguably the weakest campaign in the Black Ops series but redeems itself with a fresher and more content-filled multiplayer with its online and zombie modes. The addition of new specialists and faster, more fluid movement within more layered maps adds plenty of extra polish to the game's traditional mechanics. Zombies mode also gets extra depth in terms of both production and gameplay. Although it doesn't revolutionize shooters per se, it's one of the more polished entries in the genre this generation.

Rating: 4 out of 5

4 out of 5 Cost: $50-60; PC, PS3, PS4, X360, XB1 (Review based on PS4 version)

search_result.text:
Jason Hidalgo

jhidalgo@rgj.com

Technobubble covers games, gadgets, technology and all things geek. Follow Technobubble poobah Jason Hidalgo’s shenanigans on Twitter @jasonhidalgo

Around this time one year ago, I was lamenting the decline of the shooter genre.

Maybe it was just me. But after playing shooter after shooter for years, the genre’s newer offerings just weren’t holding my interest like they used to. A lot of it had to do with the holding pattern that new shooters seem to be stuck in. With the exception of a few games like the original Titanfall, I just wasn’t seeing any key changes or new mechanics that really propelled shooters forward, even though they certainly showed high levels of polish.

For 2016, I was expecting more of the same. Then this little game called Doom came out. A modernized take on the shooting franchise that arguably started it all, Doom represented the most fun I’ve ever had in a shooting campaign in a long time. Still, I thought Doom would simply be the exception to the rule. I’ve seen many a genre enjoy its time in the limelight from side-scrolling action games to Japanese RPGs, only to give way to the next big thing. Why would shooters be any different?

Then came Battlefield 1. Although its mechanics did not see a significant change overall, the decision to base its campaign and overall aesthetic on World War I proved to be a much welcome breath of fresh air. Suddenly, my list of fun shooters for the year have grown to two. But as they say, two is an accident. In order for something to be a trend, it has to happen three times, right?

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Lo and behold, Gears of War 4 comes out like a Lancer chainsaw busting through a wooden door. Gears of War 4’s solid gameplay wasn’t just a win for shooters in general but also for fans of the oft-ignored third-person shooting genre. Then again — to use a figure skating reference — even triple axels are passe, these days. To really get attention, you have to do a quadruple axel.

This brings us to Titanfall 2. Back in 2014, the first Titanfall game generated plenty of buzz thanks to its faster and more vertical gameplay for soldiers, as well as the addition of giant Titan robots that you can call down from the heavens. Although the game looked like the next big thing for first-person shooters, however, the decision to stay exclusive to one console ecosystem in Xbox, combined with the lack of a campaign, took out some of the luster from the game.

Blast from the past: Battlefield 1 review | Technobubble

Homecoming: Gears of War 4 review | Technobubble

Give 'em hell: Doom (2016) review | Technobubble

It’s a problem that Titanfall 2 definitely learns from as it launches on both Microsoft and Sony systems right off the bat. In addition to being more console agnostic this time around, the sequel also ties a bow around a full-fledged campaign to satisfy folks such as myself who still place great value on story modes for shooters. I say that even as someone who scored the first game highly despite my deep disappointment in its lack of a campaign due to its forward-looking mechanics.

Although Titanfall 2’s campaign appears to be the same one-man jaunt through hostile territory that’s seen in many a shooting campaign, this is actually a buddy adventure at its core — pun so totally intended. You start out as Frontier Militia rifleman Jack Cooper, a young, promising recruit who aspires to become a Titan pilot someday. During a battle with industrial conglomerate Interstellar Manufacturing Corporation, however, Cooper suddenly finds himself taking over the reigns of a classic Vanguard-class Titan known as BT-7274, or “BT” for short. Let’s just say it’s a good thing they didn’t pick DT, at least as far as the Japanese market goes. Anyway, Cooper’s unlikely transformation into a pilot kicks off a six-hour campaign where he tries to survive while unraveling the IMC’s secret plans. Along the way, Cooper develops a bond with his AI partner, which adds an extra dynamic over the lone wolf approach seen in other shooter protagonists.

I found Titanfall 2’s campaign to be quite solid, overall, thanks to an interesting story and well-designed locales that show off its unique gameplay. While shooting campaigns tend to be flat for the most part and typically use stairs, platforms and elevators for level variety, Titanfall 2 builds in verticality into its level design and mechanics. In addition to double jumps, you also encounter plenty of gaps and spaces that require you to do wall runs and wall jumps, sometimes consecutively in order to get to from point A to point B. This makes movement a more essential part of the gameplay that’s actually both challenging and exciting thanks to the use of platforming mechanics. The game also plays faster than your typical modern first-person shooter. It’s not quite as fast the fun third-person shooter from Platinum, Vanquish — a criminally underrated title in my book — but it has a tiny bit of an arena shooter feel to it.

Despite its faster speed, the actual shooting remains excellent and has that familiar rock-solid feel that you get from Respawn games and the Call of Duty series. While I typically prefer the large-scale multiplayer approach of Battlefield, including its use of vehicles, over Call of Duty’s multiplayer design, I actually preferred the feel of COD’s shooting mechanics. It just seems more solid and comfortable for me and that shooting feel is replicated here — no surprise given the Respawn team’s COD pedigree prior to its split with Activision.

Like its predecessor, Titanfall 2 also brings more to the table in multiplayer over COD due to its additional mechanics, larger levels and inclusion of Titan gameplay. Titan gameplay does get a few tweaks in multiplayer mode this time to change things up. One is the more controversial decision to eliminate regenerating shields, which changes Titan combat. This makes stringing kills more difficult while also adding more importance to strength in numbers in Titan vs. Titan encounters.

Tied to the loss of shields is the addition of battery-stealing mechanics when rodeo-riding enemy Titans. Successfully doing so lets you steal a battery, that you can then give to a friendly Titan for a health boost. As a defense, Titan pilots can discharge smoke to rid themselves of pesky rodeo riders, which can be built up to stack. You can also try to reclaim batteries by killing foes after they steal them.

Titan types, meanwhile, double up to six instead of the three from the first game. Examples include the Scorch, an incendiary-based unit that’s a bit reminiscent of the original Ogre. Other Titans specialize in defense or using rockets. Personally, my favorite is the Ronin, which has excellent melee capabilities and allows aggressive players to get up close and personal.

Multiplayer modes are also quite plentiful, including objective-based ones for folks who want to be rewarded for doing things besides killing. You also have Titan-free Pilot vs. Pilot matches or pilot-free Last Titan Standing mode for folks who want to focus on Titan vs. Titan battling. One bit of good news for multiplayer lovers is that I had no issues with the game’s online servers post-launch, with matches running fluid without disconnects and interruptions.

Downsides include enemy AI, which can be brain dead at times for both campaign and multiplayer. If you disliked the presence of AI grunts in online multiplayer before, they return in Titanfall 2 as well, though it’s admittedly nice to have them if you’re a new player trying to get used to the game or simply having a bad day against human players. I also wish multiplayer offered more in the way of stages that really took advantage of the built-in vertical gameplay to separate the game from other shooters. The platforming sections, while enjoyable for me, also can be frustrating for folks who don’t quite get the knack for it, especially when trying to chain wall runs and jumps together. All that being said, I actually enjoyed this game’s multiplayer the most out of all those good shooters I mentioned earlier.

FINAL THOUGHTS

Titanfall 2 returns with a more complete package this time around by supplementing its faster, more vertical gameplay with a much needed campaign mode. The new campaign is a huge improvement over the patchwork story from the first game and a wider selection of Titans makes multiplayer feel more diverse. Changes in Titan health mechanics, admittedly, might be a mixed bag for online players and the game’s multiplayer maps don’t fully take advantage of your pilot’s penchant for going vertical. Overall, however, Titanfall 2 is a fun romp for folks thirsty for a shooting experience that’s different from the norm.

Rating: 4.25 out of 5​

4.25 out of 5​ Cost: $59.99; PC, PS4 and XB1 (reviewed)​

By James Woodson

Video games have grown into their own separate culture but which games have changed the culture?





Pong

The Grand Theft Auto series

There has been a lot of negative attention and comments toward Rockstar Games' Grand Theft Auto series (GTA). It makes sense why parents of younger gamers see the series in a negative light. It’s crude, gory and whatever other violent adjective you can think of. Though, there is something compelling about being able to live out your criminal underworld fantasies. The game revolutionized the aspect of open-world gaming and role-play gaming. The GTA series revolutionized certain aspects of being able to interact with the world’s AI and environment. In other words, if you decide break laws, the police are going to react and attempt to arrest you. The series has sparked lots of lawsuits and scrutiny for Rockstar Games, but this has not stopped them from furthering the GTA franchise. Rockstar plans to release Grand Theft Auto V in September 2013.

GoldenEye 007

GoldenEye 007 was one of the early popular first-person shooter games. The game was released exclusively for Nintendo 64 in 1997, two years after the release of the eponymous James Bond movie. The game included iconic James Bond movie weapons such as the standard-issue Walther PPK and the Golden Gun. It sold over eight million copies worldwide and become the third best-selling N64 game of all time. The game set many standards for what is common in first-person shooter games today: various maps in “death match” multiplayer mode, zoomable sniper scopes and extensive mission objectives. Nintendo launched a successor to GoldenEye 007 for the Wii console in 2010, but it was not nearly as successful as the original.



RELATED: College gamers react to Microsoft’s Xbox One reveal

Madden NFL Football

The Madden NFL Football franchise is probably one of the most popular sports video game in the United States. The game began humbly in two-dimensions and featured pixelated figures moving rigidly up, down, left and right across a green block. It has evolved into 3-D players with fluid control of their movement, customization of how they move and detailed stadiums of NFL teams. The franchise was originally known as John Madden Football when it was first launched 1988. Madden was one of the first video games that featured commentary similar to the live game commentary of legendary broadcasters like Pat Summerall, Al Michaels and John Madden every Sunday and Monday night. The game was also one of the first game franchises to feature professional athletes on the cover. The game has become a part of real-life sports culture; ESPN has hosted Madden tournaments and competitions.

Madden 25 is set to release Aug. 27.

Halo series

Halo’s revolutionary single player storyline was great in its own right, but what made Halo so successful was the multiplayer mode. The multiplayer mode had a variety of maps and new game modes that had never been seen before. Halo’s strong multiplayer encouraged users to keep playing long after they had finished the campaign. Microsoft unleashed Xbox Live in 2002, significantly altering how the franchise developed its sequels and expansion series. The Xbox Live was first incorporated with Halo 2, giving rise to the phenomenon of online Halo multiplayer. It lead to tournaments and competitive gaming leagues that would pay the contestants based on how well they did. The main Halo franchise, centered on Master Chief John 117, came to a conclusion in 2011 with Halo 4, though there are spin-offs in development. The Halo franchise will release a third-person shooter game for Window 8 and Windows 8 Phones via download.

Call Of Duty series

The Call of Duty game series was first released in 2003 as a first-person shooter based in World War II and entirely changed that genre of video games. Call of Duty started to simulate mission-based objectives as the infantry of various Allied forces. The franchise produced seven WWII era-based games but the Infinity Ward series reached its influential apex with the Modern Warfare expansion series. The Modern Warfare series, like Halo, expanded online multiplayer and incorporated a modern setting.



Ryan Hill is a summer intern at USA TODAY College. He is also currently enrolled at the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication at Arizona State University, and he is set to graduate in 2015.

This story originally appeared on the USA TODAY College blog, a news source produced for college students by student journalists. The blog closed in September of 2017.

search_result.text:
Why hello there, old friend. That was my initial reaction to “Call of Duty: Modern Warfare,” which returns not just with a familiar name but also brings back a familiar mode to boot.

It’s a welcome return to form for the franchise, which served up a less than complete experience last time. When I reviewed “Call of Duty: Black Ops 4” last year, I found the multiplayer experience to be the best I’ve ever seen in the franchise thanks to a diversity of options for its online modes. Unfortunately, that also came at the expense of a full-fledged story, which made it feel like, well, half a game.

As a result, I called BLOPS 4 “almost the best” COD game at the time. Yes, I know I’m probably one of the few gaming dinosaurs who want my shooters to come with a dedicated campaign but I honestly just don’t think that any shooter is complete without it.

This makes the return of story mode in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare an interesting development indeed. While Call of Duty continues to be a mammoth seller in the industry, the COD entries of this console generation haven’t quite reached the highs set by previous entries. As such, it wouldn’t be surprising if Activision is banking on the positive vibes associated with the Modern Warfare name to jumpstart the latest entry in the franchise. After all, the Modern Warfare name calls back to a time when the series didn’t quite have the baggage that builds up after 16 years of continuous releases. Add the fact that the game features crossplay and dumps the traditional season pass approach for free weapon and map updates and it appears that Call of Duty: Modern Warfare is definitely trying to garner player goodwill. This is especially true following the widespread backlash against exploitative loot boxes that got kicked off by EA’s Star Wars Battlefront 2 game.

The question now is whether the latest game simply piggybacks on the Modern Warfare name or actually builds on it. As someone who’s played various iterations of the series throughout the years, the new Call of Duty: Modern Warfare has a more classic vibe to it. Yes, its visuals are certainly modern — no pun intended — boasting incredibly detailed facial modeling and highly polished production values that would make Michael Bay put on sunglasses with a smile. The gameplay and overall presentation, however, has that familiar boots-on-the-ground feel that older COD entries had, especially when it comes to the game’s campaign. For longtime fans who have been turned off by entries such as Advanced Warfare and Infinite Warfare, this truly feels akin to a homecoming of sorts.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

It’s also weird how the return to a more current timeline feels, well, refreshing. For the latest iteration, the soft reboot centers on a geopolitical conflict that should feel familiar to many folks in a post-9/11 world (or even a post-Soviet-Afghan War world). Urzikstan might be a fictional country. But the familiar themes of Middle East conflict, terrorism and foreign influence feels like it comes straight out of today’s uncomfortable reality from Afghanistan all the way to the plight of the Kurds. Whether it be the use of female freedom fighters or the interference of global powers in the Middle East’s highly volatile powder keg, Modern Warfare’s campaign pretty much puts a mirror — albeit one with Hollywood-style movie touches — that lets the player face the more inconvenient truths of today’s world. Here we are in 2019 and we still have humans committing atrocities and fighting Old World conflicts that make you question why we haven’t progressed past such incomprehensible acts as a species.

Granted, what you get from the Modern Warfare campaign largely depends on your own world view. Even as the game takes several fictional liberties, it’s just hard not to decry the problems presented in Modern Warfare, especially as a once-idealistic and hopeful youngster who has now pretty much come to accept that these conflicts likely won’t be finished in my lifetime as I’ve gotten older. Admittedly, the story doesn’t quite reach the narrative prowess of “Spec Ops: The Line.” But it’s a story mode that is still much welcome for a campaign lover such as myself, especially with its embrace of more complicated, morally gray themes.

Multiplayer, meanwhile, tries to add more variety to the series’ typical run-and-gun modes by putting added focus on larger maps as well as the return of the co-op Spec Ops mode. You still have fast-paced, twitch-style modes such as the six vs. six mode Shoot House and the even more close-quarters Gunfight. You also have classic modes such as the capture-and-hold-based Hardpoint as well as the Deathmatch-style Free For All. But then you have interesting modes such as Night Vision, which requires you to fight in the cover of darkness. Ground War, meanwhile, tries for an approach that’s more reminiscent of the Battlefield series, featuring humongous maps as well as the use of vehicles. The goal is to basically push forward into enemy territory to capture and hold objective points, allowing you to unlock more locations to spawn into. It’s a great option for folks who are either overwhelmed by the run-and-gun modes or just want to try something different.

Admittedly, this change in focus, combined with the slower and more deliberate pace, won’t be for everybody. Ground War, for example, especially rewards more tactical play, including camping — something that likely won’t sit well with some folks. Personally, I prefer this more strategic, less frenetic pace but it can be frustrating to die within a second of spawning after being sniped by a camping player, which happened in my case multiple times. I also wish the game had featured the same emphasis on destructible environs in its larger maps like Battlefield does, which would help make things more interesting. It would have been nice if the game featured more modes and maps as well as they feel a bit sparse at launch. Hopefully, some of the Modern Warfare games' classic maps are added via a future update.

Another issue with the game involves glitches. In one multiplayer session, for example, my HUD just started spazzing out while I was playing on my PS4 Pro, resulting in a distracting, vibrating mess. Others have reported glitches involving claymores and the 725 Shotgun, though these are planned to be patched via an update. Speaking of updates, the game also requires a pretty huge one the first time you play, which will likely frustrate some folks. All I can say is, I hope you have a good Internet connection.

Despite its issues, I still prefer Modern Warfare over BLOPS 4. As a more old-school player, I just like the feel of this game compared to the last few entries in the series. Add the return of a full-fledged campaign after its absence last year and Modern Warfare provides the better overall package for folks who want to have their cake and eat it, too.

FINAL THOUGHTS

After punting on a campaign mode in BLOPS4, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare represents a welcome return to form for a franchise that appeared to be on a downward trend. The more deliberate pace for multiplayer, especially for Ground War mode, might feel clunky to folks who prefer more fast-paced action. This one, however, feels more like a complete game than its predecessor. It still might not be the best COD ever for a lot of folks. But it’s certainly the best COD in quite some time, especially if you’ve been disappointed by games such as Advanced Warfare and Infinite Warfare.

Rating: 8.5 out of 10

8.5 out of 10 Cost: $59.99; PC, PS4, XB1

Jason Hidalgo

Reno Gazette-Journal

In the annals of video game history, 2017 likely will be remembered as the year that microtransactions and loot crates broke a beloved hobby.

It’s a shame given how the Year of the Fire Rooster kicked off one of the best starts I’ve seen in my decades spent as a gamer.

With an initial list that includes The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Persona 5, Resident Evil 7 and Nier Automata, the first few months of 2017 alone brought me almost a year’s worth of gaming enjoyment. Heck, I even gave out my first ever perfect-10 score as a professional reviewer this year.

In that sense, I guess you can say that the Year of the Fire Rooster was “straight fire.” Yes, that was a terrible pun. You know what isn’t terrible, though? These games in the annual Technobubble Big Game List that’s what.

Let’s start this shindig with my personal picks for the Top 25 Video Games of 2017. Note that this only includes new games and full remakes but not remasters or mildly updated versions of older games.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

The top 25

25. Sonic Mania: Boy, it’s kinda chilly today, huh? As someone who grew up playing the classic Sonic games, Sonic Mania’s retro 16-bit gameplay is a literal blast (processing) from the past. If you adore Sega Genesis-era Sonic and enchiladas, you owe it to yourself to pick this one up.

24. Monster Hunter Stories: Pokemon Ultra Sun and Moon might be getting all the attention this year for cute monster games. Monster Hunter Stories, however, is the Pokemon game a lot of us have always wanted. You mean I can capture and ride my favorite Monster Hunter monsters, er, monsties into battle? Sign me up!

23. Fire Emblem Echoes: Shadows of Valentia: One thing I love about Nintendo is its penchant for not just simply remastering games but putting in the extra effort to remake them properly. Shadows of Valentia is a perfect example, taking a classic entry in the highly regarded Fire Emblem strategy RPG series and giving it a fresh coat of paint for today’s modern times.

22. The Evil Within 2: Poor Sebastian Castellanos just can’t seem to catch a break. Shinji Mikami’s post-Resident Evil opus about the power and horrific potential of the mind — and bathtubs — features the same eerie vibe plus the addition of a more open sandbox for you to play in. It’s an interesting twist in the classic Resident Evil-style formula that adds a touch of freshness to the concept.

21: Destiny 2: Hey, maybe that spiritual medium from the 1982 Poltergeist film was right about the light after all. The shooting MMO returns with its solid mechanics plus a stronger focus on storytelling after skimping on its narrative in the previous game. Some issues remain with progression and microtransaction mechanics but folks who loved the first game will like this one.

20. Gravity Rush 2: I’m not sure why but playing Gravity Rush 2 reminds me of all the wonderful times I spent playing PlayStation and PS2 games of yore. Maybe it’s the Mega Man Legends vibe I get from it. Regardless, a really likable protagonist combined with some nifty gravity mechanics make this action-adventure game akin to a day in the clouds.

19. Cuphead: It takes a special game to erase my save data and still make it into my list of best games. But that’s just how good Cuphead is. It’s the same way its charming 1930s-style art and animation makes you forgive all the misery it puts you through with its brutal old-school difficulty. If you like games classic Contra and Gunstar Heroes, you owe it to yourself to try out this delightfully unique game.

18. Little Nightmares: In a world where many games follow established, cookie-cutter formulas, I like to reward new games that try to fit a different mold from the first-person shooters and action adventure games that rule the day. Reminiscent of last year’s excellent Inside, Little Nightmares is a side-scrolling survival game with an eerie, unique art style that sets it apart from other games. This is a game for thinkers who love suspense.

17. Toukiden 2: Mitama mia! With Monster Hunter XX not making it to Western shores, Toukiden 2 certain helps scratch that itch for monster-hunting lovers who don’t import, at least until the arrival of Monster Hunter World. This sequel melds its unique body part-slicing mechanic with a new open sandbox that distinguishes itself from its more popular rival’s hub-based world. It’s my favorite Monster Hunter clone by far.

16. Tekken 7: Hey, it’s like the 1990s again! The well-adjusted members of the Mishima family are back to impose their family drama on the world once more as the popular 3D-fighting franchise reaches its seventh installment. In addition to the series’ tight fighting mechanics, Tekken also enables one of the community’s more memorable kumbaya moments with the addition of Akuma, Geese Howard and prince pretty bromancer Noctis. That’s not so “predictabo!”

15. Nioh: I’m admittedly late to the Nioh party. But boy is this game a hoot. It’s like Ninja Gaiden, Devil May Cry, Dark Souls and Bloodborne jumped into a blender and came out as one frothy cocktail. If you like punishing yet satisfying action games that also look nice and “purdy,” you’ll definitely want to check it out.

14. Horizon Zero Dawn: Here’s another title I didn’t get to play at launch. But it definitely was in my must-play list this year after I caught up with my gaming backlog. With its compelling story and beautiful landscape, Horizon Zero Dawn pairs that style with some nice substance that lovers of action-adventure games will appreciate. It’s one of the best new IPs of this generation, for sure.

13. South Park: The Fractured But Whole: There’s probably a special place in hell for people like me who enjoy South Park’s humor. Heck, it still makes me uncomfortable sometimes. Fractured But Whole, however, is a game based on a popular franchise that’s done right as opposed to being a blatant cash grab. If you love South Park and turn-based RPG fighting, this one’s a no-brainer.

12. Metroid: Samus Returns: She’s baaaaack. A Gameboy classic gets new life on the 3DS with totally reworked visuals while retaining the classic feel of the 2D Metroid series. Folks who loved games like Super Metroid will love this Metroidvania-style game, which coincidentally was worked on by a studio that did the Castlevania: Lords of Shadow games. Now all we need is a new Metroid Prime game and we’re golden.

11. Assassin’s Creed Origins: Just as the Assassin’s Creed series was starting to feel a bit long in the tooth, its latest game breathes new life into the franchise with a change of scenery and a tortured new protagonist. Origins features some gorgeous, breathtaking locales as well as the political intrigue the series is known for. Add polished mechanics and it’s a nice return to form for the franchise.

10. Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle: As one of the few people who apparently likes the Rabbids and is older than 10, I was pleasantly surprised when this game was announced. Add Mario characters and XCOM gameplay and it became one of my most anticipated titles of the year. The good news is that the game delivered with its snarky whimsy and solid tactical RPG gameplay. It’s a family-friendly game with smarts.

9. Injustice 2: At a time when the industry is seeing a fighting game renaissance, Injustice 2 is exhibit A of what a good fighter should look like. That’s coming from someone who prefers the mechanics of Capcom’s fighting games. Injustice 2 continues NetherRealm’s penchant for flashy visuals and a narrative that doesn’t take a back seat to the fighting. Do note that it can get violent and disturbing so this isn’t for the kiddies.

8. Splatoon 2: OK, true confession, I love Splatoon 2. Perhaps more than the average person. For starters, it’s one of the few shooter-type games that I’m actually really good at. Add its colorful presentation, creative visuals and unique ink-based shooting mechanics and you have a game that’s easy to pick up and lots of fun to play for the young and young at heart. The addition of a horde mode is icing on the cake, er, batter on the calamari.

7. Xenoblade Chronicles 2: As someone who pines for the golden age of JRPGs, Xenoblade Chronicles 2 really hits the spot. This checks a lot of the boxes for my JRPG fix from its wonderfully designed locales and colorful characters to its intriguing story and hours upon hours of gameplay. The English localization is a bit hit or miss but you can thankfully download a Japanese language option, bruzzah.

6. Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus: Despite being part of a genre that has been over-marketed, overplayed and overdone in the last few generations, I was dumbfounded by just how much Wolfenstein II surprised me at various turns of its narrative. I mean, some plot points are just so outlandish, I totally did not predict what was going to happen. This game, as well as Wolfenstein I and the new Doom, have basically made me fall in love with first-person shooters once more.

5. Resident Evil 7: We’re now entering hallowed territory with Capcom’s survival horror reboot opening the Top 5. After getting a bit tired with the last few installments, Resident Evil 7 takes a risk by dropping its third-person tradition and going first-person to great effect. Heck, I prefer third-person games myself but RE7 manages to retain the claustrophobia of the series while ramping up the scares. Play it on VR and prepare to wet your “pantalones.”

4. Nier Automata: Gosh, I love this game. I really, really, really love it. Chalk it up to the unusual decision to serve up an odd narrative while mashing up multiple genres into one unexpected package and actually making it work. It’s got side-scrolling shooting, top-down shooting, corridor action and even a grindy open sandbox. Honestly, how this pupu platter concept didn’t end up as a glorious disaster is beyond me. Just like being weird works well for Portland, Oregon and Santa Cruz, California, the same can be said for Nier Automata for sure.

3. Mario Odyssey: The Mario series does it again by serving up a fun new adventure that manages to make a mascot that’s been around forever feel fresh once again. The twist this time around comes with the addition of sandbox gameplay that encourages more exploration and experimentation, as well as the ability to take over and control Goombas, Bullet Bills and even a, uh, tree. Honestly, this easily could have been my No. 1 game depending on what side of the bed I wake up in the morning.

2. Persona 5: I was a nanometer away from giving this game a 10 out of 10. That’s how much I enjoyed playing what I now consider one of the best JRPGs I’ve ever come across. Persona 5 is a great example of a what a modern JRPG should be. It pays homage to the mechanics and design of the past but also adds a new kind of flair that takes out that stale derivative taste while adding a hip vibe to the game. You’ll never see it coming.

Game of the year

Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild: Given the success of the critically acclaimed Zelda franchise, you’d certainly hate to be the one to kill the golden goose. Which makes the Zelda team’s decision to take a risk and introduce a massive open-world mechanic to the game even more commendable. Breath of the Wild takes the familiar Zelda conventions and thrusts it into a new open environment that encourages so much player creativity that it feels like a living world. And while the narrative is minimal as with past Zelda games, they still can tug your heartstrings at choice moments, with the Mipha arc literally making me cry. Dang it, I wanna cry right now just thinking about it. Hold up, I think I got something in my eye.

And that’s this year’s list of top video games. Curious about which games made the cut in prior years? Here’s a look back at my annual picks from the rose-colored past.

Technobubble covers games, gadgets, technology and all things geek. Follow Technobubble poobah Jason Hidalgo’s shenanigans on Twitter @jasonhidalgo or his Tabiasobi Youtube channel.
